entries: While attuned to the Pnakotic Manuscripts, you gain the following benefits:

items: You double your bonus to {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}.
You gain a +10 bonus to {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.
You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all Dexterity saving throws.
You gain a +1 bonus to AC.
Once per turn while moving, you can teleport back to any spot you occupied during your current move.

entries.name: Drawbacks:
entries: You age at an accelerated rate. After one week, you age an additional week. After two weeks, you age an additional four weeks. After three weeks, you age an additional six weeks, and so on. If you remove your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to this item and later attune to it again, you preserve this drawback's progress.

entries.name: Insight-No Time to Tarry (+15):
entries: You hate any activity that takes more than a few moments. You grow impatient as your attention fades and you seek something new to do, leaving critical work unattended as you start a new project or seek out something new to do.

entries.name: Lore:
entries: The Pnakotic Manuscript allows you to automatically succeed all checks made to learn about time and its nature.

item.name: Seven Cryptical Books of Hsan
item.reqAttune: by a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB} check)
entries: These seven scrolls each cover a different topic concerning the relationship between the gods, the material world, and the planes. Those who master them can create doors to other worlds.

entries.name: Language:
entries: {@language Celestial|XPHB}.

entries.name: Attunement Check:
entries: Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) DC 20. To end your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to the Seven Cryptical Books of Hsan, you must visit each of the seven realms that it allows access to.

entries.name: Benefits:
entries: While attuned to the Seven Cryptical Books of Hsan, you gain the following benefits:

items: If you have the spellcasting class feature, you can prepare one additional spell for each spell level you can cast. That spell must be chosen from the Cleric spell list.
You gain a +1 bonus to the DC of any spell you cast that is on the Cleric spell list.
You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all Wisdom saving throws.
You gain one additional spell slot of the highest level you can use.

You can cast {@spell Gate|XPHB} once per day without expending a spell slot. Wisdom is your casting ability for this spell. When you cast it, you open a gate to a location described in the books. If you use this feature again while at the location, the spell connects to the second location in the books. There are seven such locations, and using this feature at the seventh one returns you to the place where you first used this ability. The specific locations are left to the DM to decide, but legend has it that each is a domain of a long forgotten deity since claimed by agents of the Cthulhu Mythos.

entries.name: Drawbacks:
entries: You have an overwhelming drive to use the books to visit the realms it allows you to access. If you go a week without using the Gate feature, you gain a level of {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} that you cannot lose until you cast {@spell Gate|XPHB} using this item and travel through the portal you created.

entries.name: Insight-Enemy of the Dark (+20):
entries: You are an ardent foe of the Cthulhu Mythos. When you encounter their agents and entities, you are compelled to defeat them and drive them back to the dark corners of the cosmos that spawned them. You struggle to leave any location that has been overrun with their foul evil.

entries.name: Lore:
entries: The Seven Cryptical Books of Hsan allows you to automatically succeed all checks made to learn about dead gods.

item.name: The King in Yellow
item.reqAttune: by a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB} check)
entries: A thin, leather-bound volume, The King in Yellow contains a dreamlike play that compels a reader to obsess over the text. They read the play again and again, slowly coming to believe that the disconnected scenes and strange vistas it describes are real.

entries.name: Language:
entries: {@language Common|XPHB}.

entries.name: Attunement Check:
entries: Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) DC 15. Unlike other tomes, you are compelled to make this check when inspecting The King in Yellow. If you succeed, you attune to the book. To end your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to the King in Yellow, you must meet Hastur.

entries.name: Benefits:
entries: While attuned to The King in Yellow, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all Charisma ({@skill Performance|XPHB}) checks.
You gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) checks as long as your lie involves characters, scenes, and locations drawn from The King in Yellow.

You can cast {@spell Contact Deity|CthulhuTorchlight}. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell. Once you use this feature, you cannot use it again until you finish a long rest. When you cast that spell using this item, you always contact Hastur.

Each time you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1 you can cast {@spell Call Deity|CthulhuTorchlight} to summon Hastur. You lose access to this benefit if you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} without using it. If you do not use the spell, you gain a level of {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} that cannot be removed while you are attuned to this item.

entries.name: Drawbacks:
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on all Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}), Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}), and Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks, as images of Carcosa dance in your mind, distracting you from the increasing unreal world around you.

entries.name: Insight-Lost Carcosa (+20):
entries: You must find lost Carcosa and gaze upon forgotten Lake Hali. There, in that dreadful realm, you will finally find peace. No matter the cost, you must find the path there. You see omens and signs of Carcosa in the strangest places. The depths of ancient dungeons. The entrails of a slain enemy. Every sign points you back to Carcosa, again and again.

entries.name: Lore:
entries: The King in Yellow allows you to automatically succeed all checks made to learn about Hastur and elements associated with it.

item.name: Witchboard

items.name: Ability:
entries: Charisma

items.name: Utilize:
entries: Exchange messages of up to 10 words with an Ethereal creature within 30 feet (DC 15).

A witchboard is a slat of wood covered with letters, usually the Common alphabet though versions for different scripts are available. You can use it to contact Ethereal creatures, allowing limited conversations with them.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The colour out of space casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 12}):

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The colour out of space has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The colour out of space makes two Draining Lash attacks.

action.name: Draining Lash
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9}, Reach 15 ft. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) Necrotic damage.

action.name: Absorb Life {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 17}, non-Mythos creatures in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} centered on the colour out of space. {@actSaveFail} 44 ({@damage 8d10}) Necrotic damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage. If three or more creatures fail their saving throw against this effect, the colour out of space gains an additional action on its next turn.

bonus.name: Horrid Burrowing
entries: The colour out of space destroys an unattended, non-magical object that it can touch that has {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} less than or equal to the colour's maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Dagon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (4/Day)
entries: If Dagon fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: One With the Sea
entries: When Dagon drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or would be killed outright, it instead transforms into a swirling body of water. At the start of each of Dagon's turns, it gains one recovery point but otherwise cannot use actions or legendary actions other than Relentless Horror. When it gains its fourth recovery point, its maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} return to normal if they have been reduced and it regains all lost {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. It reforms its physical body in a space of its choice within 10 miles of its location. It then loses all recovery points.

If Dagon is the target of a {@spell Banishment|XPHB} spell cast with a 9th-level spell slot while in this cloud form, it automatically fails its saving throw and is instead sent to the deepest corner of the ocean where it slumbers for {@dice 6d10} years.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: Dagon deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Spectral Waves
entries: Storm-tossed waves formed of magical force swirl around Dagon in a 120-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from him. Creatures without a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} treat this area as Difficult Terrain and take 10 Force damage if they end their turn in this area. Flying creatures that end their turn in this area must make {@dc 24} Strength saving throws, gaining the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition on a failed save.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Dagon makes four Slashing Claw attacks.

action.name: Slashing Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 17}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) Slashing damage and the target is pushed up to 10 feet away from Dagon and gains the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Hungry Tide {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 24}, creatures of Dagon's choice within 120 ft. of it; {@actSaveFail 1} The target takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) Force damage, and gains the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn, when it repeats the save. {@actSaveFail 2} The target takes {@dice 4d20} (22) Force damage its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced to 0 and cannot be increased until it uses an action to make a successful {@dc 24} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

legendary.name: Disdainful Swipe
entries: Dagon makes a Slashing Claw attack.

legendary.name: Storm Tossed Seas
entries: {@actSave str} {@dc 25}, creatures within 120 ft. of Dagon of its choice; {@actSaveFail} Dagon moves the target up to 30 feet and the target gains the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

legendary.name: Relentless Horror {@recharge 5}
entries: Dagon chooses one of the following options:

items: It teleports up to 200 ft. to an unoccupied space.
It immediately ends one spell or condition affecting it.
It ends one spell or magical effect of its choice within 120 ft. of it.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The deep one casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 12}):

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The deep one can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The deep one has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deep one makes two claw and one bite attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, Reach 10 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) Slashing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) Piercing damage.

trait.name: Mythos Fanaticism
entries: If the deep one hybrid can see a Mythos creature of size Large or larger, it gains a +5 bonus to Initiative rolls and gains 2 {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} at the start of its turn.

action.name: Trident
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) Piercing damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 2}, range 80/320 ft. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8}) Piercing damage.

reaction.name: My Life for Yours
entries: {@actTrigger} A Mythos creature without this Reaction is hit by a melee attack. {@actResponse} This creature becomes the target of the triggering attack if it is in range of the original attack.

trait.name: Dimensional Attunement
entries: A dimensional shambler gains 1 Dimension Point at the end of its turn during combat or when it is otherwise threatened. It begins an encounter with 0 points and can have up to 4.

trait.name: Dimensional Warping
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 14}, if a creature within 30 feet of the dimensional shambler attempts to teleport. {@actSaveFail} The creature doesn't teleport. {@actSaveSuccess} The creature teleports as normal.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The dimensional shambler has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dimensional shambler makes up to four Dimensional Claw attacks and uses Disdainful Banishment. It can't attack the same creature more than twice with Dimensional Claw when it uses Multiattack.

action.name: Dimensional Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, Reach 10 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) Slashing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 16}). It can Grapple up to two Medium or smaller creatures at a time.

action.name: Disdainful Banishment
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 14}, one creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by the dimensional shambler. {@actSaveFail} The target is teleported up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space the dimensional shambler can see.

bonus.name: Dimensional Flurry
entries: A dimensional shambler can spend 3 Dimension Points to gain an extra use of Legendary Action. It must use the additional use before its next turn.

bonus.name: Dimensional Rend
entries: A dimensional shambler can spend 1 Dimension Point to extend its claws through space and time, increasing its Reach with Dimensional Claw to 30 feet and allowing it to ignore all cover with those attacks until the end of its turn.

bonus.name: Dimensional Step
entries: A dimensional shambler can spend 3 Dimension Points to teleport itself and all creatures it has {@condition Grappled|XPHB} to a chosen destination it has visited within the past month.

bonus.name: Teleport
entries: The dimensional shambler teleports up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The dimensional shambler makes up to two Dimensional Claw attacks.

legendary.name: Shift
entries: The dimensional shambler uses Dimensional Step.

legendary.name: Step
entries: The dimensional shambler uses Teleport.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder thing casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 15}):

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The elder thing has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder thing makes up to two Grasping Tentacle attacks and uses Spellcasting.

action.name: Grasping Tentacle
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d8 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 18}). While {@condition Grappled|XPHB} the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition.

action.name: At Will:
entries: {@spell Charm Person|XPHB}, {@spell Scorching Ray|XPHB}, {@spell Thunderwave|XPHB}.
1/day: {@spell Cone of Cold|XPHB}, {@spell Fear|XPHB}, {@spell Ice Storm|XPHB}.

bonus.name: Surgical Eye
entries: The elder thing assesses the anatomy of a creature it can see within 30 ft. and makes a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Medicine}) check. If it succeeds, its attacks against the target are critical hits on die rolls of 18 or higher for the next minute or until it uses Surgical Eye against a different target. If the elder thing succeeds on this check a second time against the same creature, its attacks against the target are instead critical hits on die rolls of 16 or higher for the next minute or until it uses Surgical Eye against a different target.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The elder thing makes a Grasping Tentacle attack.

legendary.name: Ghoulish Study
entries: The elder thing uses Surgical Eye.

legendary.name: Sudden Movement
entries: The elder thing moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The flying polyp has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The flying polyp makes up to four Grasping Tentacle attacks and uses Wind Blast (if available).

action.name: Writhing Tentacles
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 14}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}16 ({@damage 1d10 + 10}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 24}). While {@condition Grappled|XPHB}, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Wind Blast {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave str} {@dc 24}, each creature in a 20-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} centered on a point the flying polyp can see within 120 feet. {@actSaveFail} 18 ({@damage 4d8}) Cold damage and the target is pushed up to 30 feet away from the flying polyp in a straight line. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

bonus.name: Grasping Wind
entries: {@actSave str} {@dc 24}, on creature within 2,000 feet. The flying polyp must have an unblocked line between it and its target, but the line does not need to be straight. The polyp does not need to see the target. {@actSaveFail} The target's {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced to 0 and cannot be increased until the end of the flying polyp's next turn. {@actSaveSuccess} No effect.

bonus.name: Invisibility {@recharge 5}
entries: The flying polyp gains the {@condition Invisible|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The flying polyp makes a Writhing Tentacles.

legendary.name: Sudden Movement
entries: The flying polyp moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The formless spawn casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 12}):

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The formless spawn can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch without expending extra movement to do so.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The formless spawn has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The formless spawn makes up to four attacks, using Bludgeoning Pseudopod or Grasping Tentacle in any combination. It can replace any number of attacks with uses of Crushing Grip or Throw Victim.

action.name: Bludgeoning Pseudopod
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, Reach 10 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Crushing Grip
entries: {@actSave str} {@dc 18}, one creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by the formless spawn. {@actSaveFail} 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Bludgeoning damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

action.name: Grasping Tentacle
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) Slashing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 18}), and it has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the grapple ends.

action.name: Throw Victim
entries: The formless spawn throws a Medium or smaller creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by it to a space it can see within 30 feet of itself that isn't in the air. {@actSave dex} {@dc 18}, the creature thrown and each creature in the destination space. {@actSaveFail} 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Bludgeoning damage, and the target has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The gnoph-keh has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gnoph-keh makes six Rending Claw attacks.

action.name: Rending Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, Reach 10 ft. {@h}12 ({@damage 1d8 + 7}) Slashing damage.

bonus.name: Heart of the Storm
entries: The gnoph-keh can generate a supernatural storm that fills the area around it in a howling blizzard. Driving snow and wind fill the area in a 300-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} centered on the gnoph-keh. The area is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB}, and exposed flames in the area are doused. This effect ends if the gnoph-keh has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition or dies. It can also dismiss the effect as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.
A creature that ends its turn in this {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) Cold damage.

trait.name: Even Death May Die
entries: When Great Cthulhu drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or would be killed outright, it instead transforms into a cloud of green mist that fills its space. At the start of each of Great Cthulhu's turns, it gains one recovery point but otherwise cannot use actions or legendary actions other than Relentless Horror. When it gains its fourth recovery point, its maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} return to normal if they have been reduced and it regains all lost {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. It reforms its physical body in a space of its choice within 10 miles of its location. It then loses all recovery points.

If Great Cthulhu is the target of a {@spell Banishment|XPHB} spell while in this cloud form cast with a 9th-level spell slot, it automatically fails its saving throw and is instead sent to R'lyeh where it slumbers for {@dice 10d10} years.

trait.name: Horrid Aura
entries: A non-mythos entity that starts its turn within 30 feet of Great Cthulhu takes 10 Psychic damage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (6/Day)
entries: If Great Cthulhu fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Great Cthulhu makes six Crushing Claw attacks.

action.name: Crushing Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 19}, Reach 25 ft. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d8 + 10}) Bludgeoning damage and the target is either knocked {@condition Prone|XPHB} or moved up to 20 ft. in a straight line from Great Cthulhu.

action.name: Apocalyptic Majesty {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 23}, creatures of Great Cthulhu's choice that can see or hear it within 500 ft. {@actSaveFail 1} The target takes 110 ({@damage 20d10}) Psychic damage, and is {@condition Frightened|XPHB} of Great Cthulhu until the end of its next turn, when it repeats the save. {@actSaveFail 2} On its next turn, Great Cthulhu controls the target. This effect ends at the end of that turn.

legendary.name: Disdainful Swipe
entries: Great Cthulhu makes two Crushing Claw attacks.

legendary.name: Relentless Horror {@recharge 5}
entries: Great Cthulhu chooses one of the following options:

items: It teleports up to 200 ft. to an unoccupied space.
It immediately ends one spell or condition affecting it.
It ends one spell or magical effect of its choice within 120 ft. of it.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Yithian casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 17}):

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Yithian has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Time Master
entries: When the Yithian rolls {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, it may choose to treat the result of its {@dice d20} roll as a 5 or 15. It may also apply this effect to up to six willing creatures it can see.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Yithian makes two Snapping Claw attacks.

action.name: Snapping Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 11}, Reach 15 ft. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) Slashing damage.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Yithian makes a Snapping Claw attack.

legendary.name: Spell
entries: The Yithian uses Spellcasting, but can only cast spells it can use at will.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lesser crawling one casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 18}).

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The greater crawling one has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Implacable Evil
entries: When a greater crawling one is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it falls into a pile of rotting flesh, worms, and maggots. If it takes at least 40 Fire damage before the end of its next turn, the greater crawling one is permanently destroyed. It can still be targeted by spells and effects that target creatures. Otherwise, the greater crawling one reforms in {@dice 2d6} days. The new body appears in an unoccupied space within the tomb it was originally buried in.

action.name: Slimy Grasp
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) Necrotic damage.

legendary.name: By My Command
entries: The greater crawling one chooses up to three willing Undead or Mythos creatures it can see. Each of the chosen creatures can take a Reaction to move up to its Speed, and each creature gains Advantage on the next attack roll it makes before the greater crawling one's next turn.

legendary.name: Squirming Escape
entries: The greater crawling one teleports up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The greater dark young of Shub-Niggurath casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 18}):

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The greater dark young of Shub-Niggurath has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The greater dark young of Shub-Niggurath makes four Flailing Tentacle attacks. It can replace two attacks with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Flailing Tentacle
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, Reach 30 ft. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 18}).

legendary.name: Swarming Tentacles
entries: The greater dark young of Shub-Niggurath makes two Flailing Tentacle attacks.

legendary.name: Clamor of Hooves
entries: The greater dark young of Shub-Niggurath moves up to its Speed.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The greater star-spawn of Cthulhu casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 17}):

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The greater star-spawn of Cthulhu can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The greater star-spawn of Cthulhu has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The greater star-spawn of Cthulhu makes two Crushing Fist attacks.

action.name: Crushing Fist
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 11}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d10 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage.

legendary.name: Flabby Claws
entries: The greater star-spawn of Cthulhu makes a Crushing Fist attack.

legendary.name: Eldritch Contradictions
entries: The greater star-spawn of Cthulhu uses Spellcasting.

legendary.name: Ravening for Delight
entries: The greater star-spawn of Cthulhu moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hunting horror casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}):

trait.name: Light Sensitivity
entries: While in {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB}, the hunting horror has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and checks.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hunting horror has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hunting horror makes one Bite attack and one Tail attack, It can replace one attack with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) Piercing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 18}).

bonus.name: Prey's Doom
entries: The horror unravels a target's life force with a bite. The hunting horror studies one creature it can see within 30 feet of itself. For 1 minute, once on each of the hunting horror's turns when it hits the target with an attack roll using its Bite attack, it can cause the target to take an extra 18 ({@damage 4d8}) Necrotic damage, and the target can't regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} until the end of hunting horror's next turn. On each of the hunting horror's subsequent turns, it can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to deal 18 ({@damage 4d8}) Necrotic damage to the target automatically.

This effect ends if the target is ever outside the range, if it has {@variantrule Cover|XPHB|Total Cover} from the hunting horror, if it is on a different plane of existence, or if hunting horror uses this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on a different creature.

legendary.name: Gnashing Teeth
entries: The hunting horror makes one Bite attack.

legendary.name: Crushing Horror
entries: A creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by the hunting horror takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) Bludgeoning damage.

legendary.name: Pursuit of Prey
entries: The hunting horror moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lesser crawling one casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}):

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The lesser crawling one has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Relentless Evil
entries: When a lesser crawling one is reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, it falls into a pile of rotting flesh, worms, and maggots. If it takes at least 15 Fire damage before the end of its next turn, the lesser crawling one is permanently destroyed. It can still be targeted by spells and effects that target creatures. Otherwise, the lesser crawling one reforms in {@dice 2d6} days. The new body appears in an unoccupied space within the tomb it was originally buried in.

action.name: Slimy Grasp
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 3}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) Necrotic damage, and a Medium or smaller creature has its Speed reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn as it is covered in slime and maggots.

legendary.name: By My Command
entries: The lesser crawling one chooses up to three willing Undead or Mythos creatures it can see. Each of the chosen creatures can take a Reaction to move up to its Speed, and each creature gains Advantage on the next attack roll it makes before the lesser crawling one's next turn.

legendary.name: Squirming Escape
entries: The lesser crawling one teleports up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lesser dark young of Shub-Niggurath casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}):

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The lesser dark young of Shub-Niggurath has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lesser dark young of Shub-Niggurath makes four Flailing Tentacle attacks. It can replace two attacks with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Flailing Tentacle
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 13}).

legendary.name: Swarming Tentacles
entries: The lesser dark young of Shub-Niggurath makes two Flailing Tentacle attacks.

legendary.name: Clamor of Hooves
entries: The lesser dark young of Shub-Niggurath moves up to its Speed.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lesser star-spawn of Cthulhu casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}):

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The lesser star-spawn of Cthulhu can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The lesser star-spawn of Cthulhu has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lesser star-spawn of Cthulhu makes two Crushing Fist attacks.

action.name: Crushing Fist
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, Reach 15 ft. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) Bludgeoning damage.

legendary.name: Flabby Claws
entries: The lesser star-spawn of Cthulhu makes one Crushing Fist attack.

legendary.name: Eldritch Contradictions
entries: The lesser star-spawn of Cthulhu uses Spellcasting.

legendary.name: Ravening for Delight
entries: The lesser star-spawn of Cthulhu moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The mi-go casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 15}):

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The mi-go has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Space Traveler
entries: The mi-go does not need to breathe air.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mi-go makes two Claw attacks and uses Spellcasting.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) Piercing damage.

bonus.name: Hideous Counsel
entries: The mi-go confers with a human brain it has sealed away in a jar. The specimen is specifically chosen for the knowledge it can provide to the mi-go, allowing it to adapt to a variety of situations. The mi-go chooses one of the following benefits: It gains {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls until the end of its turn.
It uses the Dodge action as part of this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.
It gains a +2 bonus to its spell save DC until the end of its turn.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Nyarlathotep casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 20}):

trait.name: Defeat from Victory
entries: When Nyarlathotep drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or would be killed outright, he is not slain. Instead, his body ripples with energy as it undergoes a horrific transformation. He returns to whatever strange realm he dwells in as his defeated form is torn apart by unseen forces. Mythos creatures with a combined CR of up to 20 emerge from the pile of gore, occupying the nearest, empty space. These creatures attack those who were hostile to Nyarlathotep and fight to the death.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (4/Day)
entries: If Nyarlathotep fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Nyarlathotep has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Poisoned Words, Rotten Soul
entries: A creature that succeeds in a Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) check to detect one of Nyarlathotep's lies takes 66 ({@damage 12d10}) Psychic damage and cannot communicate with other creatures for {@dice 3d6} minutes. A creature killed by this trait appears to have died of a heart attack or similar cause.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Nyarlathotep makes two Rending Claw attacks and two Piercing Talon attacks.

action.name: Rending Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 14}, Reach 15 ft. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) Slashing damage and the target gains the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Piercing Talon
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 14}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}14 ({@damage 1d10 + 8}) Piercing damage. {@condition Prone|XPHB} creatures have {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB} to this attack's damage.

action.name: Horrid Tongue Lash {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 24}, creatures of Nyarlathotep's choice within 20 ft. of it; {@actSaveFail} The target takes 66 ({@damage 12d10}) acid damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

action.name: Shape-Shift
entries: Nyarlathotep shape-shifts into a Small or Medium Humanoid, or it returns to this form. Other than his size, his game statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment he is wearing or carrying isn't transformed.

legendary.name: Swift Claw
entries: Nyarlathotep makes a Rending Claw attack.

legendary.name: Incite Delirium
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 20}, one creature within 120 ft. of Nyarlathotep of its choice; {@actSaveFail} The target uses its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to make a weapon attack against a target of Nyarlathotep's choice.

legendary.name: Relentless Horror {@recharge 5}
entries: Nyarlathotep chooses one of the following options:

items: It teleports up to 200 ft. to an unoccupied space.
It immediately ends one spell or condition affecting it.
It ends one spell or magical effect of its choice within 120 ft. of it.

trait.name: Hexing Aura
entries: Each creature of the rat-thing's choice in a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the rat-thing gains a +1 bonus to its spell save DC.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The rat-thing has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d3 + 2}) Piercing damage.

hp.special: 50 (Assassin only) or 40 (Infiltrator only) + 10 for each spell level above 5

trait.name: Incorporeal Passage
entries: The spirit can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. If it ends its turn inside an object, it is shunted to the nearest unoccupied space and takes {@damage 1d10} Force damage for every 5 feet traveled.

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: The spirit may take the {@action Hide|XPHB} action as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} when in {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB} or {@variantrule Darkness|XPHB}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The spirit makes a number of attacks equal to half this spell's level (round down).

action.name: Chill Touch (Infiltrator Only)
entries: {@atkr m} {@hitYourSpellAttack Bonus equals your spell attack modifier}, Reach 5 ft. {@h}{@damage 1d8 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} Cold damage.

action.name: Deathly Bolt (Assassin Only)
entries: {@atkr r} {@hitYourSpellAttack Bonus equals your spell attack modifier}, range 150 ft. {@h}{@damage 2d4 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} Cold damage. If the spirit was hidden when it made the attack, the attack deals an additional {@damage 2d4} Cold damage.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The shoggoth can move through a space as narrow as 1 foot without expending extra movement to do so.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The shoggoth can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The shoggoth has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shoggoth makes four attacks, using Horrid Tendril or Hurled Mucous in any combination. It can't attack the same target more than once.

action.name: Horrid Tendril
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 15}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}21 ({@dice 2d10 + 10}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 20}), and it has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the grapple ends. It can Grapple up to four Large or smaller creatures at a time.

action.name: Hurled Mucous
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 15}, range 200 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) Acid damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Slime Wave {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 20}, each creature in a 60-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 44 ({@damage 8d10}) Acid damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage. For 1 minute, the area within the {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone} is drenched with slimy acid. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, it takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) Acid damage. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

bonus.name: Horrid Digestion
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 23}, one creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by the shoggoth. {@actSaveFail} The target takes 32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) Acid damage.

legendary.name: Thrash of Shifting Forms
entries: The shoggoth makes a Horrid Tendril or Hurled Mucous attack.

legendary.name: Bear Down Upon
entries: The shoggoth moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ancient shoggoth casts one of the following spells, using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 17}):

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The shoggoth can move through a space as narrow as 1 foot without expending extra movement to do so.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The shoggoth can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The shoggoth has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shoggoth makes four attacks, using Horrid Tendril or Hurled Mucous in any combination. It can't attack the same target more than once.

action.name: Horrid Tendril
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 15}, Reach 20 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) Bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 20}), and it has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition until the grapple ends. It can Grapple up to four Large or smaller creatures at a time.

action.name: Hurled Mucous
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 15}, range 200 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) Acid damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Slime Wave {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 20}, each creature in a 60-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 44 ({@damage 8d10}) Acid damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage. For 1 minute, the area within the {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone} is drenched with slimy acid. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, it takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) Acid damage. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

bonus.name: Horrid Digestion
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 23}, one creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by the shoggoth. {@actSaveFail} The target takes 32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) Acid damage.

legendary.name: Thrash of Shifting Forms
entries: The shoggoth makes a Horrid Tendril or Hurled Mucous attack.

legendary.name: Bear Down Upon
entries: The shoggoth moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

trait.name: Boundless Horror
entries: When Shub-Niggurath drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or would be killed outright, it instead transforms into a swarm of insects that fill its space. At the start of each of Shub-Niggurath's turns, it gains one recovery point but otherwise cannot use actions or legendary actions other than Relentless Horror. When it gains its fourth recovery point, its maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} return to normal if they have been reduced and it regains all lost {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. It reforms its physical body in a space of its choice within 10 miles of its location. It then loses all recovery points.
If Shub-Niggurath's space is filled with magical fire it is banished from the world and prevented from returning for {@dice 4d10} years.

trait.name: Horrid Garden
entries: Horrid vines, slick acidic dew and covering in flesh, gnawing mouths erupt from the ground in a 120-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from Shub-Niggurath. The effect of this trait depends on its level. When Shub-Niggurath rolls initiative, set this trait's level to 0. The trait's level increase by 1 after each of Shub-Niggurath's turns to a maximum of 3. Use the highest AC bonus granted by this trait. Shub-Niggurath gains the benefits of this trait's current level and all lower ones. These benefits end when Shub-Niggurath is no longer threatened by hostile creatures.

entries.name: Level 0
entries: No effect.

entries.name: Level 1
entries: The ground in the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB} for non-Plants. At the end of Shub-Niggurath's turns, including the turn in which this trait reached level 1, two awakened trees appear in open spots in the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} of Shub-Niggurath's choice. They immediately roll initiative and aid their Dark Mother.

entries.name: Level 2
entries: A non-plant takes 15 Acid damage, or 30 Acid damage if it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition, when it ends its turn in the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}.

entries.name: Level 3
entries: Plants have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all attack rolls made against non-Plants in the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}. A creature hit by a Plant's melee attack gains the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (4/Day)
entries: If Shub-Niggurath fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Shub-Niggurath makes four total Grasping Tendril and Stomping Hoff attacks.

action.name: Grasping Tendril
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 17}, Reach 30 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 2d10 + 10}) Bludgeoning damage and the target is moved to the open space closest to Shub-Niggurath.

action.name: Stomping Hoof
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 17}, Reach 10 ft. {@h}32 ({@damage 4d10 + 10}) Bludgeoning damage and the target gains the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: The Earth Hungers {@recharge}
entries: {@actSave str} {@dc 25}, creatures of Shub-Niggurath's choice within 200 ft. of Shub-Niggurath and the ground. {@actSaveFail} The target takes 110 ({@damage 20d10}) Bludgeoning damage, is pulled to the ground beneath it if it is flying, and gains the {@condition Prone|XPHB} and {@condition Restrained|XPHB} conditions as fibrous plant tendrils erupt from the ground. It repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. After 1 minute, it succeeds automatically. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage, and the target is pulled to the ground beneath it if it is flying.

bonus.name: Tree Walk
entries: Shub-Niggurath may teleport to any open space, provided she ends that teleportation within 10 feet of a friendly Plant creature she can see.

legendary.name: Hungry Tendril
entries: Shub-Niggurath makes a Grasping Tendril Attack

legendary.name: Rapid Maneuver
entries: Shub-Niggurath uses its Tree Walk {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}. It can't take this action again until the start of its next turn.

legendary.name: Relentless Horror {@recharge 5}
entries: Shub-Niggurath chooses one of the following options:

items: It teleports up to 200 ft. to an unoccupied space.
It immediately ends one spell or condition affecting it.
It ends one spell or magical effect of its choice within 120 ft. of it.

monsterFluff.name: Colour Out of Space

entries: The shaft of phosphorescence from the well brought a sense of doom and abnormality which far outraced any image their conscious minds could form. It was no longer shining out, it was pouring out; and as the shapeless stream of unplaceable colour left the well it seemed to flow directly into the sky.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Colour Out of Space

entries: A colour out of space is a sentient organism that is an insubstantial, amorphous patch of color. It glistens in the light, displaying a variety of mind-bending colors that have no analog in the spectrum familiar to living folk. It pours across the ground or seeps through the air, always seeking new victims to devour.

entries.name: Unholy Colonists
entries: A colour out of space emerges from the depths of the dark void between the stars. It falls to the ground and begins to subvert and corrupt the environment around it. Its voracious hunger and baleful presence causes the ecosystem to wither and rot. Plants grow wild, but they are covered with tumors and warped growths. Animals and insects are born with twisted limbs, strange coloration, and hideous fangs and claws. These creatures prey upon those who stumble into the infested region, turning the area into a wasteland. These beasts and other living creatures that dwell in the area, including humans, take on the colour's strange hue and work to keep the colour safe from outside interference.

entries.name: A Legacy of Ruin
entries: The colour out of space drains the life from the region it infests, the growing corruption and ecological ruin mirroring its ability to drain the area's life and vitality. Eventually, the region is rendered utterly barren. Even the warped plants and creatures that result from the colour's influence die out. The colour, having sated its hunger, then departs into space.

entries.name: Homefield Advantage
entries: The area infested by the colour offers a variety of benefits to the creatures that aid it. Creatures under the colour's influence gain the Mythos tag and the following benefits while active in the region it feeds upon:

items: They ignore the effects of {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}.
They have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on all Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) and Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks.
They have {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} with a range of 10 feet.

monsterFluff.name: Crawling One

entries: Wisely did Ibn Schacabac say, that happy the town at night whose wizards are all ashes. For it is of old rumor that the soul of the devil-bought hastes not from his charnel clay, but fats and instructs the very worm that gnaws; till out of corruption horrid life springs, and the dull scavengers of earth wax crafty to vex it and swell monstrous to plague it. Great holes secretly are digged where earth's pores ought to suffice, and things have learnt to walk that ought to crawl.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Festival

entries: A crawling one is composed of thousands of worms and maggots. Each worm is individually alive and constantly squirms, though, together, they generally hold the shape of a human body. The collective mass of wriggling creatures possesses the mind of a dead spellcaster, long since devoured by the maggoty horde. The ingested "will" of the mage effectively drives the mass to continue the mage's foul deeds.

entries.name: Ambition Beyond the Grave
entries: A crawling one arises from the baleful will of a dead cultist. When a powerful spellcaster, usually one pledged to the Cthulhu Mythos, dies, the mage's ambition, evil, and thirst for power linger on. This aura of evil acts as a beacon, drawing hungry worms and maggots to the moldering corpse. As the vermin devour the body, the spellcaster's evil presence spreads throughout the devourers. They become a collective entity that allows the cultist to arise once more.

entries.name: Relentless Malevolence
entries: A crawling one's true threat lies in its ability to live on despite horrid wounds. If a small mass of the worms and maggots that comprise its form escapes, it can incorporate more vermin into its body and regain its full power.

entries.name: Generational Threat
entries: This horrid regrowth allows a crawling one to pursue its awful plans over generations. These creatures often recruit allies and cultists from among mortals, offering them great power in return for service. A clever crawling one keeps to the background, forming a secret conspiracy with but a few of its closest followers. If the cult faces defeat, the crawling one fades into the background and waits for the opportunity to rise again. Even when seemingly destroyed by adventurers, it relies on its ability to reform its body to outlast its enemies.

monsterFluff.name: Dagon

entries: Vast, Polyphemous-like, and loathsome, it darted like a stupendous monster of nightmares to the monolith, about which it flung its gigantic scaly arms.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, Dagon

entries: Dagon is a deep one who has grown to enormous size. Perhaps millions of years old, this cruel tyrant of the undersea realm strives to free Cthulhu from his deep slumber in the sunken city of R'lyeh. Dagon is the high priest of Cthulhu among the Deep Ones. Under his direction, that loathsome species seeks to infiltrate and overwhelm the terrestrial realms.

entries.name: Unwitting Servitors
entries: Dagon sits at the head of the cults established among human villages by the deep ones. Careful to avoid calling too much attention to their true aims, these cults ultimately serve Cthulhu but few in their ranks know this. The cult, under the direction of their deep one leaders, offers aid to Cthulhu cults and works to foil those who would hunt down and destroy them. To most of the humans caught in this scheme, Dagon is a benevolent sea deity who offers excellent fishing and good weather.

entries.name: Hidden Horrors
entries: While Dagon is considered the most powerful of the deep ones, other, similarly ancient creatures have gained similar levels of power. Deep one writings refer to Mother Hydra, an entity said to be Dagon's equal. Who can say what other terrors may lurk in the ocean's depths.

entries.name: Storm of the Century
entries: Dagon rarely interacts with mortals, but does intervene when a particularly bothersome foe arises or to preserve a critical aspect of his cult. Dagon's magic manifests as a halo of arcane, stormy sea waters that swirl around him. This destructive energy allows him to emerge on shore and walk through a village, town, or fortress that troubles his cult. This magic lashes out at the place, battering to ruin and slaying those within. When authorities come to investigate, they find a ruin that seems to have been devastated by a terrible storm. Dagon and the deep ones always ensure that no survivors remain to contradict this assumption.

monsterFluff.name: Dark Young

entries: An enormous writhing mass formed of ropy black, earthwormlike tentacles. Something like twenty feet tall. Here and there, across the surface were great puckered mouths that dripped green goo. Beneath its central mass, two or three thicker tentacles terminated in enormous black hooves, on which it stamped forward. It carried the visage of some ancient gnarled tree when its shape was cast against the moon. The smell was appalling, like the stench of open graves.
entries.from: Malleus Monstrorum Volume I: Monsters of the Mythos

entries: These horrid abominations are the "young" referred to in Shub-Niggurath's epithet: "Black Goat of the Woods with a Thousand Young." They are closely connected to her and are found only in areas where she is worshiped. The dark young act as proxies for Shub-Niggurath, crawling from the darkness to accept sacrifices and devour the unwary.

entries.name: Noxious Heralds
entries: The dark young are the first of Shub-Niggurath's servitors to contact a cult. Those who worship the Black Goat of the Woods engage in primal rituals that require gratuitous bloodletting and fleshy offerings. In return, the dark young heed their call. They provide a cult with brute force, smashing its enemies and protecting it from outsiders. However, if the cult fails to provide a steady stream of sacrifices, the dark young may cull its weakest members, devouring them to slake its hunger and 'encourage' the cult to become more aggressive toward outsiders.

entries.name: Corrupting Influence
entries: The presence of a dark young shifts and warps the natural world. The plants in a 5-mile radius centered on its lair grow thick and verdant, creating natural barriers to dissuade explorers and intruders. Cultists learn the hidden paths that crisscross the area, allowing them to move in relative ease while intruders struggle. Animals become overly aggressive and vicious, attacking non-cultists on sight. In game terms, treat the area as {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. A DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check and 1d4 hours of searching allows a traveler to uncover the pathways. A DC 25 Wisdom ({@skill Survival|XPHB}) check is needed to use the trail to reach the cult's lair.

monsterFluff.name: Deep One

entries: It was a thin, stoop-shouldered man not much under six feet tall... His age was perhaps thirty-five, but the odd, deep creases in the sides of his neck made him seem older when one did not study his dull, expressionless face. He had a narrow head, bulging, watery blue eyes that seemed never to wink, a flat nose, a receding forehead and chin, and singularly undeveloped ears.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Shadow over Innsmouth

entries: Along lonely coasts, where few live and even fewer travel, the ghastly cult of Cthulhu and his servitors takes root. The deep ones are aquatic creatures that live in undersea colonies located in the darkest depths. Within these cities, they conduct loathsome rites to their chief deities, Dagon, Mother Hydra, and Cthulhu.

entries.name: Insidious Corruptors
entries: The deep ones spy upon isolated coastal communities, keeping watch for signs of weakness or decay. If a village falls upon hard times, the deep ones make their move. They come ashore and approach the villagers peacefully, promising bountiful fishing, protection from monsters, and shelter from storms. Like a shepherd tending to wayward sheep, the deep ones tend to the humans while slowly making them wholly dependent upon their care.

entries.name: Generational Evil
entries: If the human community proves malleable, especially after culling a few dissidents, the deep ones further their corruption. In a grand ceremonial feast, they declare that the land folk have proven their worth and can now truly join with their aquatic protectors. The final step involves the deep ones marrying into prominent human clans to bind the villagers by blood. The children of these grotesque arrangements are deep one hybrids. While they are born human, they slowly and torturously transform into hybrids once they reach adulthood.

entries.name: A Slow Corruption
entries: In time, the village becomes fully integrated into deep one culture. The hybrid villagers maintain the faade of normalcy, venturing into civilization as needed or dealing with outsiders as appropriate. Meanwhile, the deep ones expand their influence to nearby settlements and lure more into their twisted cult.

monsterFluff.name: Dimensional Shambler

entries: Shuffling toward him in the darkness was the gigantic, blasphemous form of a black thing not wholly ape and not wholly insect. Its hide hung loosely upon its frame, and its rugose, dead-eyed rudiment of a head swayed drunkenly from side to side. Its fore paws were extended, with talons spread wide, and its whole body was taut with murderous malignity despite its utter lack of facial expression.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft and Hazel Heald, The Horror in the Museum

entries: Little is known about these beings save for their name and a vague description provided by the scant few who have survived these horrors. They are capable of walking between the realms of the universe, and they constantly move, spending little time at a location.

entries.name: Horrid Travelers
entries: Dimension shamblers enlisted by Mythos cults use their unerring teleportation to retrieve lost artifacts or helpless victims. Usually, the shambler deposits its quarry with its nominal allies, but, other times, it carries off its victim to an unknown destination for an unknown reason.

entries.name: Cosmic Detritus
entries: Before her disappearance, the sage Lemetra of the Endless Hourglass conducted chronomantic research into the origin of the dimensional shamblers. She wrote letters to each of her closest friends, pleading with them to visit her tower to review her findings. When they arrived, they found the tower scoured of almost everything. The only remnant was a fragment of a scroll hidden in a secret cache. It described a multiverse that existed before ours, and of strange refugees from it that sought to unwind time and replace this reality with their own.

monsterFluff.name: Elder Thing

entries: They represented some ridged barrel-shaped object with thin horizontal arms radiating spoke-like from a central ring and with vertical knobs or bulbs projecting from the head and base of the barrel. Each of these knobs was the hub of a system of five long, flat, triangularly tapering arms arranged around it like the arms of a starfish.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, Dreams in the Witch House

entries: The bizarre elder things predate all other known forms of life, or so sages believe. Ancient ruins, archaeological evidence, and even entreaties to the gods seem to indicate that the elder things existed in the universe even before the gods arose.

entries.name: Ancient Remnants
entries: In their heyday, the elder things dug deep into the lore around the Cthulhu Mythos. They crafted the first shoggoths and used them to erect great, cyclopean cities. They warred against the mi-go and the star-spawn of Cthulhu for dominance over the primordial world, and were eventually defeated when the shoggoths grew too cunning and overthrew them.

entries.name: Scattered Remnants
entries: A few elder things remain, though they are scattered and isolated. Now and again a mortal sage or spellcaster may come into contact with one. They can offer strange insights to those who learn their bizarre, piping, whistling language.

entries.name: Slumbering Threats
entries: In some cold corners of the world, ancient ruins built by the elder things remain undisturbed. These creatures slumber there, having plunged into a hibernation in the ancient days in order to outlast the threats they faced. When outsiders uncover these ruins, the elder things awaken and set to work. Driven by a scientific approach to the world, they may catch, study, and dissect any humanoids they encounter. They use their magic and cunning to cultivate worship and obedience, turning neighboring creatures into cultists to help them achieve their inscrutable aims.

monsterFluff.name: Flying Polyp

entries: A horrible elder race of half polypous, utterly alien entities... They were only partly material and had the power of aerial motion, despite the absence of wings... Suggestions of a monstrous plasticity and of temporary lapses of visibility... singular whistling noises and colossal foot-prints made up of five circular toe marks seemed also to be associated with them.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Shadow Out of Time

entries: Almost nothing is known of the dreaded flying polyp. The details of their culture, the motivations behind their actions, and even the name they use to refer to themselves are complete mysteries.

entries.name: Abandoned Domains
entries: The flying polyps once gathered in great cities. They constructed vaults deep within the earth. Stone wells bored through the rock and dirt allowed the polyps access to their strongholds. When they departed the world, they sealed these wells with stone caps. Only a patient climber, or a creature capable of flight, can navigate the long, deep wells to reach the polyp ruins below.

entries.name: Masters of the Air
entries: While flying polyps are powerful combatants, their most potent attacks is their ability to control the weather. When three or more of these creatures gather, they can conjure howling wind storms that scour an entire region of life. It takes an hour for three or more polyps working together to create a storm. When they finish their ritual, a terrible storm rips through the area in a 5-mile radius around the ritual site. The storm lasts for an hour and flattens all buildings that lack fortifications. Creatures caught in the open take 1d4 Bludgeoning damage per minute until they find shelter.

monsterFluff.name: Formless Spawn

entries: When the men of K'n-Yan went down into N'Kai's black abyss... they found living things... amorphous lumps of viscous black slime... They did not pause for detailed observations, and those who escaped alive sealed the passage.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft and Zealia Bishop, The Mound

entries: These black, protean beings change shape in an instant, from toad-like lumps to elongated things with hundreds of rudimentary legs. They ooze through small cracks or enlarge to block entire passages.

entries.name: Alarmingly Intelligent
entries: Despite their ooze-like form, formless spawn are cunning, malevolent entities spawned by the Cthulhu Mythos. They lurk in forgotten shrines and ruins, guarding ritual relics and reacting swiftly to any intrusion.

entries.name: Relentless Guardians
entries: Formless spawn often guard sacred Mythos objects. If an intruder steals such a relic, the spawn relentlessly tracks them to reclaim it, never stopping until the object is recovered.

monsterFluff.name: Gnoph-Keh

entries: The storm sprang upon us in a moment... When I heard the distant growls erupt like approaching thunder, I had no choice but to follow the guides. We lost half our number to the blizzard, but not a one of us would have survived had we stayed to face the creature that brought that storm.
entries.from: Barabos Tollnek

entries: The gnoph-keh is a six-limbed horror that dwells high in the cold mountains. These creatures have an unclear, but indisputable, tie to the Mythos. What is plain is that gnoph-kehs rule as vicious, hateful gods among the mountain tribes they enslave.

entries.name: Terrible Deities
entries: A gnoph-keh craves worship and obedience. When it arrives in a mountainous region, it besieges the land with conjured blizzards, forcing local tribes into submission. It culls its new servants, slaying those who defy it and making the most obsequious its priests. It demands sacrifices in return for magical protections.

entries.name: Herald of a Greater Power
entries: The gnoph-keh instructs its followers to conduct bizarre rites in honor of Mythos deities such as Ithaqua. Its ultimate goal is to prepare its tribes to summon these greater powers.

monsterFluff.name: Great Cthulhu

entries: A monster of vaguely anthropoid outline, but with an octopus-like head whose face was a mass of feelers, a scaly, rubbery-looking body, prodigious claws on hind and fore feet, and long, narrow wings behind. This thing... was of a somewhat bloated corpulence... It lumbered slobberingly into sight and gropingly squeezed its gelatinous green immensity through the black doorway... A mountain walked or stumbled.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Call of Cthulhu

entries: Cthulhu dwells in the corpse city of black R'lyeh, sunken deep beneath the surface of the ocean. He is in a living death while there, but someday the city will rise and he will wake, freed to roam and slay across the world. In the city are also entombed other members of Cthulhu's species. Cthulhu is evidently the high priest and ruler of them all and is by far the most potent.

entries.name: A Fitful Slumber
entries: Cthulhu's cultists are often drawn to his worship by strange dreams triggered by his stirring within R'lyeh. As ages pass and the stars shift in the sky, Cthulhu shifts from a deep slumber to fitful dreaming. In the later state, his dreams echo across the world and coalesce into frightful visions that plague those with a gift for psychic or magical ability.

entries.name: Doomsday Cult
entries: The cults of Cthulhu are dangerous because of their splintered, disorganized nature. They arise in all cultures and among all sentient humanoids. Fighting the cult is like trying to stomp out a forest fire. You might douse an ember, but for each one you extinguish three more take root and erupt into flames. No method has yet been found to permanently defeat this foul creature.

monsterFluff.name: Great Race of Yith

entries: Enormous, iridescent cones, about ten feet high and ten feet wide at the base, and made up of some ridgy, scaly, semi-elastic matter. From their apexes projected four flexible, cylindrical members, each a foot thick, and of a ridgy substance like that of the cones themselves. These members were sometimes contracted almost to nothing, and sometimes extended to any distance up to about ten feet. Terminating two of them were enormous claws or nippers. At the end of a third were four red trumpet-like appendages. The fourth terminated in an irregular yellowish globe some two feet in diameter and having three great dark eyes ranged along its central circumference... Surmounting this head were four slender grey stalks bearing flowerlike appendages, whilst from its nether side dangled eight greenish antennae or tentacles. The great base of the central cone was ringed with a rubbery grey substance which moved the whole entity through expansion and contraction.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Shadow Out of Time

entries: The great race of Yith are creatures of the distant past, existing in a strange era before the gods forged the cosmos. In this bizarre time, they existed in an uneasy truce with other, strange creatures of the Cthulhu Mythos. Eventually, they were among the creatures swept away by the arrival of the dreaded flying polyps. The Yithians' story would have ended there, except these creatures had long studied and meddled with the flow of time. Observing that they were doomed to be destroyed by the flying polyps, they enacted a grand plan to cast their minds forward to scout the future, find a suitable home, and eventually cast their minds to that era.

entries.name: Temporal Explorers
entries: The Yithians have developed the ability to cast their minds through space and forward in time. They use this talent to explore the future in search of a new home. When a Yithian time travels, its mind enters the body of a creature it has chosen to displace. The creature's mind falls back in time, entering the Yithian's strange form.

The Yithians interrogate the creature that now inhabits the body of the time traveler, asking extensive questions about the creature's world, history, theology, and other topics. Endlessly curious and driven by a commitment to rigorous, academic research, the Yithians take care to document their captive's answers and verify the information they gather. Once the Yithians are satisfied, their captive is allowed relative freedom to dwell among the Yithians and other time-displaced captives.

Meanwhile, the time-traveling Yithian adopts the creature's identity. It conducts extensive study of the historical era, traveling far and wide in order to learn as much as it can of the time period. A Yithian typically spends five years exploring an era.

entries.name: Colonists of the Time Stream
entries: If the location seems promising for colonization, the Yithian explorer creates a cult among the locals. Promising them great magic and technology, it primes them to support the wave of Yithian explorers who are set to arrive after it logs its report in the distant past. These newcomers are other time travelers, sent forward to prepare for the arrival of the rest of the Yithians. The cult is designed to provide muscle, logistical support, and other assistance. Time travel is difficult for the Yithians. They must build up ritual sites in the future to increase their capacity to travel to an era. They rely on the cult to keep their work secret and protect them from nosy outsiders.

entries.name: Insidious Infiltration
entries: Yithian cults provide advice and guidance to their masters, helping them determine the best folk to replace with migrating Yithians. By displacing nobles, religious leaders, and others, the Yithians can ensure that their culture becomes the dominant force in a region before the entire civilization jumps forward in time.

While the Yithians are cunning and care nothing for the fate of those creatures they send back in time, they are also patient. A determined resistance to their scheme can, if it proves troublesome enough, force the Yithians to give up their plans and seek easier pickings.

However, if a the Yithian plot has moved far along they are loath to give up on their progress. In a dire situation, they may expend the resources needed to travel through time in their true forms, bringing to bear one last show of force to destroy any who would thwart them.

monsterFluff.name: Hunting Horror

entries: And in the air about him were great viperine creatures, which had curiously distorted heads, and grotesquely great clawed appendages, supporting themselves with ease by the aid of black rubbery wings of singularly monstrous dimensions.
entries.from: August Derleth, The Lurker at the Threshold

entries: Hunting horrors serve Nyarlathotep's bidding across the cosmos, and even into the unknown outer realms. Cultists who venerate the Crawling Chaos sometimes contact these creatures, receiving dictates, omens, and secrets in the profane rituals dedicated to the Stalker Among the Stars.

entries.name: Relentless Pursuers
entries: As their name implies, these otherworldly terrors hunt. Spellcasters who bind them use them as assassins, bat-winged killers who hunt with inhuman intensity. Once a hunting horror is directed toward a target, the horror stalks its quarry until it's slain or the horror is destroyed. Their bite corrupts and necrotizes flesh from within in moments.

entries.name: Sinister Truths
entries: As servitors of Nyarlathotep, hunting horrors rarely share their motivations or goals. They are loyal only to their master and serve mortals only when it benefits the Crawling Chaos.

entries.name: Creatures of the Night
entries: Hunting horrors loathe bright light, especially sunlight. They are active only at night, and by day dwell within cavernous lairs.

monsterFluff.name: Mi-Go

entries: They were pinkish things about five feet long; with crustaceous bodies bearing vast pairs of dorsal fins or membranous wings and several sets of articulate limbs, and with a sort of convoluted ellipsoid, covered with multitudes of very short antenna, where a head would ordinarily be...
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Whisperer in Darkness

entries: The mi-go, also known as the fungi from Yuggoth, are a species that dwell in the dark spaces between the stars. They survive in vacuum and travel through space, typically establishing colonies on high mountain peaks to mine rare minerals.

entries.name: Cult Leaders
entries: The mi-go sometimes need minions for labor. They draw humanoids into servitude through magic, promises of power, and Mythos worship. These cults help the mi-go better control their operations.

entries.name: Strange Scientists
entries: Intelligent and inquisitive, mi-go approach the world scientifically. They gather information and relics without concern for human life, viewing mortals as no more than animals.

entries.name: Bizarre Technologies
entries: Mi-go sometimes remove the brains of useful humans and preserve them in special cylinders, allowing continued communication. These brains may number in the dozens in a mi-go colony.

monsterFluff.name: Nyarlathotep

entries: A tall, slim figure with the young face of an antique pharaoh, gay with prismatic robes and crowned with a pshent that glowed with inherent light... the fascination of a dark god or fallen archangel, and around whose eyes there lurked the languid sparkle of capricious humor.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath

entries: Nyarlathotep is the messenger of the Cthulhu Mythos, a dreaded entity who appears in humanoid form to interact with mortals. He mocks the gods he serves and spreads madness, fear, and paranoia.

entries.name: A God Among Mortals
entries: Prophecies say Nyarlathotep will bring about the world's end. He delights in mortal affairs, adopting disguises to manipulate, corrupt, and destroy societies from within.

entries.name: Herald of the Mythos
entries: Nyarlathotep is invoked in nearly all Mythos rituals. When deities enter the world, he may be nearby, relishing the chaos they bring.

entries.name: Scourge of a Thousand Forms
entries: He takes many forms, often appearing as members of different humanoid species. He spreads Mythos worship, corrupts mortals with promises of power, and thrives on societal collapse.

monsterFluff.name: Rat-Thing

entries: The bones of the tiny paws, it is rumoured, imply prehensile characteristics more typical of a diminutive monkey than of a rat; while the small skull with its savage yellow fangs is of the utmost anomalousness, appearing from certain angles like a miniature, monstrously degraded parody of a human skull.
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Dreams in the Witch House

entries: From a distance, a rat-thing looks like a normal rodent. However, a close inspection reveals hideous details. Its head is a twisted caricature of a human's and its forepaws are tiny hands.

entries.name: Chittering Advisors
entries: Rat-things provide insight into arcane lore and lost history for the desperate and the mad, but each bit of knowledge comes tainted with the secrets of the Mythos. They offer advice freely, but always in service of a dark agenda.

entries.name: Horrid Familiars
entries: Owing to their otherworldly nature, rat-things cause the tides of magic to ebb and flow. Their presence strengthens the spells of Mythos creatures, making them harder to resist.

monsterFluff.name: Shoggoth

entries: It was a terrible, indescribable thing vaster than any subway train—a shapeless congeries of protoplasmic bubbles, faintly self-luminous, and with myriads of temporary eyes forming and un-forming... Still came that eldritch, mocking cry—"Tekeli-li! Tekeli-li!"
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, At the Mountains of Madness

entries: Shoggoths are vast sacks of protoplasm capable of forming limbs, eyes, and mouths at will. They are amphibious and exhibit strength that defies reality.

entries.name: Dangerous Allies
entries: Shoggoths grow more intelligent with age. Young ones are obedient brutes, but older ones may overthrow their masters and take over cults.

entries.name: Immortal Terrors
entries: Effectively immortal, some shoggoths labor in ruins long after their summoners perish, or sleep in sealed vaults awaiting release.

monsterFluff.name: Shub-Niggurath

entries: I! Shub-Niggurath! The Black Goat of the Woods with a Thousand Young!
entries.from: H.P. Lovecraft, The Whisperer in Darkness

entries: Shub-Niggurath is a primordial entity of fertility and unrestrained life. Her cults embrace primal existence and renounce civilization, favoring growth and survival above all else.

entries.name: Twisted Promises
